name: Carrots
serving_suggestions: Raw or cooked, cut into bite-sized pieces to prevent choking
portion_guide: 1-2 baby carrots for small dogs, 3-5 for large dogs as treat
description: Carrots are excellent healthy treats for dogs and cats. High in fiber and vitamin A, low in calories. Crunchy texture helps clean teeth. Serve raw or cooked, cut appropriately to prevent choking hazard.

name: Blueberries
serving_suggestions: Fresh or frozen, use as training treats
portion_guide: 2-3 blueberries for small dogs, 5-10 for large dogs
description: Blueberries are superfood for pets, packed with antioxidants, fiber, and vitamins. Low calorie makes them perfect training treats. Both fresh and frozen work great.

name: Plain Cooked Chicken
serving_suggestions: Boneless, skinless, no seasonings. Boiled or baked.
portion_guide: Small pieces as treats or meal topper. Up to 10% of daily calories.
caution: Remove all bones (cooked bones splinter). No skin (high fat). No seasoning.
description: Plain cooked chicken is excellent protein source for dogs and cats. Boneless, skinless chicken breast or thigh, boiled or baked without any seasonings, oils, or garlic. Great for sensitive stomachs or as meal topper.

name: Pumpkin (Plain)
serving_suggestions: Plain canned pumpkin (NOT pie filling) or fresh cooked
portion_guide: 1-2 tablespoons for dogs, 1 teaspoon for cats
caution: Must be plain pumpkin, NOT pumpkin pie filling (contains sugar and spices)
description: Plain pumpkin is excellent for digestive health. Helps with both diarrhea and constipation due to high fiber content. Rich in vitamins. Use plain canned pumpkin or fresh cooked, never pie filling which contains harmful ingredients.

name: Green Beans
serving_suggestions: Fresh, frozen, or canned (no salt added), cut into pieces
portion_guide: A few beans as treat or up to 10% of meal
description: Green beans are low-calorie, high-fiber vegetable great for weight management in pets. Can be served raw, steamed, or canned (no salt). Some dogs love them as crunchy treats.

name: Apples
serving_suggestions: Remove core and seeds (contain cyanide). Cut into slices.
caution: MUST remove core and seeds - apple seeds contain cyanide
description: Apples are healthy treat providing fiber and vitamins. Crunchy texture helps clean teeth and freshen breath. CRITICAL: Always remove core and seeds as apple seeds contain cyanide which is toxic. Serve only flesh in small slices.

name: Watermelon
serving_suggestions: Remove seeds and rind. Serve flesh only in small cubes.
portion_guide: A few small cubes as occasional treat
caution: Remove all seeds and rind (can cause intestinal blockage)
description: Watermelon is refreshing, hydrating treat perfect for hot days. 92% water content. Remove ALL seeds and rind completely - these can cause digestive upset or blockage. Serve only seedless flesh in small cubes.

name: Sweet Potatoes
serving_suggestions: Cooked (baked, boiled, steamed). NO raw, NO seasoning, NO butter.
portion_guide: 1-2 tablespoons for dogs as treat or meal addition
caution: Must be cooked. Raw sweet potato difficult to digest.
description: Sweet potatoes are nutritious source of fiber, vitamins, and complex carbs. Must be cooked (baked, boiled, or steamed) plain with no butter, salt, or seasonings. Raw sweet potato is hard to digest. Great energy source.

name: Plain Rice
serving_suggestions: White or brown rice, cooked plain. Mix with boiled chicken for bland diet.
portion_guide: Small amount as meal addition or for upset stomach
description: Plain cooked rice (white or brown) is bland, easily digestible carbohydrate. Commonly used for dogs with upset stomach, often mixed with boiled chicken. No butter, salt, or seasonings.

name: Plain Yogurt
serving_suggestions: Plain, unsweetened Greek or regular yogurt. Small amounts.
portion_guide: 1 tablespoon for small dogs, 2-3 for large dogs
caution: Must be plain and unsweetened. NO flavored yogurt (sugar/xylitol). Some dogs lactose intolerant.
description: Plain unsweetened yogurt provides probiotics for digestive health, plus calcium and protein. Must be plain - no sugar, no artificial sweeteners (especially xylitol which is toxic). Start with small amount as some dogs are lactose intolerant.
